Dear Ms. Skinner:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff pushed youth down and dragged him across the parking lot.
Investigation On 12/5/24 Chief Administrator reported it was alleged that
Youth A was pushed down to the ground and dragged across the
parking lot by Staff 1. This allegedly occurred on 12/4/24. Youth A
sustained scratch marks and a big bruise across his back. Staff 1
was placed on administrative leave, pending an investigation.
Chief Administrator was not sure exactly how the bruises and
scratches occurred as Youth A was not always truthful about
things. Youth A initially said he fell down after leaving the building.
Chief Administrator was contacted via email on 12/5/24 and
reported they did not have any additional information.
Interviews:
MDHHS Worker was contacted by phone on 12/6/24 to
coordinate interviews. However, interviews were rescheduled for
12/16/24, due to worker illness. On 12/16/24 MDHHS Worker
reported they had attempted to briefly interview Youth A on
12/6/24. However, Youth A refused the interview.
Program Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/16/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Program Manager
reported Youth A initially refused a medical on the day of the
incident, but later went to the hospital. Program Manager reported
Youth A recently went AWOL and had not returned. Program
Manager agreed to notify DCWL and MDHHS Worker when Youth
A returned. On 12/23/24 Program Manager contacted DCWL and
MDHHS Worker via email to report Youth A was no longer placed
at the facility, as he was moved to a juvenile detention facility due
to charges stemming from an incident while AWOL.
2

Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/16/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 denied pushing or
dragging Youth A. Staff 1 stated Youth A was outside, standing by
the fence to the employee parking lot. Youth A looked upset. Staff
1 walked over and asked Youth A if he wanted to talk about
anything. Youth A did not respond. Staff 1 tapped Youth A’s arm
and asked again if he wanted to talk. Youth A pulled away and
tried to swing his fist at Staff 1. Staff 1 stated he tried to block a
second hit by putting Youth A in a “bear hug”. Staff 1 stated his
intent was to protect himself, but also to help Youth A calm down.
Youth A was twisting and moving around. Staff 1 stated they
became unbalanced and fell. Staff 1 clarified Youth A landed on
his back, with Staff 1 on top of him. Staff 1 moved off Youth A but
believed Youth A hit his back on the parking lot gate sensor when
he fell. Staff 2 walked over to assist, and Youth A got up and ran
away. Youth A later came back and apologized to Staff 1. Staff 1
apologized to Youth A and asked if he wanted to get checked out
at the hospital. Youth A declined and signed a refusal form. Staff
1 stated he could not recall which other staff were present, as it
was dark and snowing out during the incident. Staff 1 denied
observing any marks on Youth A’s back. Staff 1 confirmed he was
not trained in one-person standing restraints and was not
permitted to initiate a restraint by himself. Staff 1 stated that in
hindsight he realized he should have known better and called for
assistance when Youth A became physical. Staff 1 reported he
had never been involved in an incident of this nature and had no
disciplinary action on file prior to this.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 12/30/24. Chief Administrator stated she did not witness the
incident. Staff 1 was immediately placed on leave when the
allegations were reported. Staff 1 remained on leave until the
investigation was completed. Chief Administrator was waiting for
the findings of the investigation before deciding if Staff 1’s
employment would continue. The reported behavior seemed very
uncharacteristic for Staff 1. However, Chief Administrator was
aware that prior to starting his shift on 12/4/24, Staff 1 received
devastating news about a murder in his family. Not that it was an
excuse for his behavior, but it may have contributed to Staff 1’s
unexpected behavior. On 1/8/25, Chief Administrator emailed
DCWL and MDHHS Worker to report the decision was made to
terminate Staff 1’s employment.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported he worked on
12/4/24. Staff 2 had just ended his shift and was sitting in his
3

vehicle in the employee parking lot, waiting for his car to warm up.
It was snowing that day and visibility was not great, but when he
looked up, he saw Staff 1 and Youth A in a “scuffle”. Staff 2 got
out of his car and went to assist. Staff 1 and Youth A were going
back and forth at one another. Staff 1 appeared to be holding the
shoulders of Youth A, but not in a way that was trained in Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPI). Staff 2 stepped in to separate them.
Youth A refused to tell Staff 2 what happened. Staff 2 stated he
did not observe anyone on the ground at any point. The incident
occurred in the employee parking lot by the fence, but Staff 2 did
not see anyone against the fence. Staff 2 stated Staff 1 always
had a good relationship with Youth A. Youth A would typically talk
to Staff 1 over anyone else at the facility. Youth A could be very
agitated at times and make threats towards people, but Staff 1
was always successful at getting Youth A to calm down and
discuss issues. This is why the situation on 12/4/24 was surprising
to Staff 2. Staff 2 stated after separating them, Youth A was upset
and pacing. When Staff 2 asked what happened, Staff 1 said
Youth A was upset and tried to punch him. When Youth A tried to
swing at Staff 1 a second time, Staff 1 grabbed Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she left her
shift on 12/4/24 at the same time as Staff 2. However, she pulled
out of the parking lot, realized she forgot something and parked
along the street in the front of the building. Staff 3 ran inside to
retrieve something, came out, and observed Youth A standing by
the parking lot gate with Staff 1. Youth A’s fists were balled up and
he appeared upset. Youth A was staring at Staff 1, as if he were
about to start a fight. Youth A jumped at Staff 1. Staff 1 pushed
Youth A down to the ground. Youth A started kicking Staff 1. Staff
1 grabbed Youth A’s leg and dragged him across the pavement,
about two feet. Staff 3 walked over and told Staff 1 repeatedly to
stop. Staff 2 then approached to assist. Staff 3 was unsure what
Staff 2 saw due to it being dark and snowing. Staff 2 grabbed Staff
1 and pulled him away from Youth A. Staff 3 did not observe any
injuries on Youth A. Staff 3 denied seeing Staff 1 attempt any CPI
techniques prior to pushing Youth A. Staff 3 saw Youth A jump at
Staff 1, but did not see Youth A hit Staff 1.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at his new placement on
1/6/25. Youth A did not have any visible marks or bruises on him
at that time. Youth A reported he preferred being at Wolverine
Center, as he had more freedom there. Youth A stated while at
Wolverine Center he had some favorite staff, but Staff 1 was not
one of them. Youth A stated Staff 1 slammed him on his back and
4

dragged him. Youth A explained that the incident occurred around
7-8:30PM in the parking lot at Wolverine Center. Youth A was
upset that night. Staff 1 was in a bad mood due to a family
member passing away. Youth A stated when he was upset, he ran
out of the building. Youth A hit Staff 1 because he was upset. Staff
1 then picked Youth A up by his shoulders and slammed him on
his back, on the ground. Staff 1 then attempted to drag Youth A.
Staff 3 tried to get Staff 1 to let go of him. Staff 2 also appeared,
but did not do anything. Youth A stated he then got up and ran
away from the building. Youth A reported he eventually returned to
the building, and no one spoke with him about the incident. Youth
A stated he had scratches and bruises on his back, that have
since healed. Youth A denied ever telling anyone that he received
the bruises from falling down.
MDHHS Worker was contacted via email on 1/27/25. MDHHS
Worker reported they were awaiting additional documentation to
conclude their investigation. However, there would be findings.
Documents reviewed:
• Employee file for Staff 1: Staff 1 was hired on 2/20/24. Staff
1 completed Orientation and CPI training as required. Staff
1 did not have any disciplinary action on file, other than an
attendance issue on 4/15/24.
• Client Recipient Rights Grievance Form dated 12/4/24,
authored by Youth A. Youth A reported he was in the
parking lot when Staff 1 dragged and slammed him to the
ground.
• Incident Report dated 12/4/24 authored by Staff 1. The
report stated Youth A reported his back was hurt from
falling when he went AWOL. Youth A stated he slipped and
fell and did not want to go to the hospital. Refusal
paperwork completed. Youth A cleaned area and did not
want anything for pain.
• Client Refusal Form dated 12/4/24, completed by Staff 1.
Staff 1 indicated on the form that Youth A refused a
medical clearance after returning from AWOL. Youth A did
not sign the form.
• Written statement dated 12/4/24, authored by Staff 2. Staff
2’s written statement was consistent with information
reported when interviewed.
• Written statement dated 12/4/24, authored by Staff 3. Staff
3’s written statement was consistent with information
reported when interviewed.
5

• Incident Report dated 12/6/24 signed by Chief
Administrator. Youth A was transported to the hospital to
have his back checked.
• Emergency Department report dated 12/6/24. Youth A
reported he was in an argument with staff two days prior.
Youth A stated he was thrown to the ground and dragged
on the ground. Youth A had superficial abrasions to the
right flank of his back, but did not have any pain or
tenderness. There was also a large scratch to his left
posterior shoulder. No tenderness reported. Youth A had
full range of motion.
• Emergency Department report dated 12/15/24. Youth A
reported applying antibacterial ointment to scrape on his
back observed by provider on 12/6/24. Youth A returned to
provider due to ongoing pain at the site. Youth A was given
ibuprofen. Well healing 8cm superficial scrape observed to
left posterior shoulder. Patient was discharged with no
other concerns.
• Behavior Support and Management policy indicates staff
are to use non-violent restrictive intervention to contain a
client’s acute physical behavior, to maximize safety and
minimize harm. This is only to be used to protect client or
others from unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior
that places them at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs. Staff are to use CPI non-
violent crisis intervention methods as trained.
Analysis A violation was found as interviews with the youth and staff
confirmed that Staff 1 did not follow agency policy regarding
physical management.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
